sen.j: 北野天満宮（きたのてんまんぐう）は京都市上京区にある神社である。
sen.e: Kitano-tenmangu Shrine is a Shinto shrine in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Kitano-tenmangu Shrine is a Shinto shrine in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Kitano-tenmangu Shrine is a Shinto shrine in Kamigyo-ku Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 通称、天神さん・北野さん。
sen.e: It is also known as Tenjin-san and Kitano-san.
It is also known as Tenjin-san and Kitano-san.
It is also known as Tenjin-san (heavenly gods) and Kitano-san.
sen.cmt: 「天神」の英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: 旧社格は官幣中社。
sen.e: It was formerly classified as a Kanpeichusha shrine under the old system of shrine classifications.
It was formerly classified as a Kanpeichusha shrine under the old system of shrine classifications.
It was formerly classified as a Kanpei Chusha shrine (middle-scale government shrines).
sen.cmt: 「官幣中社」の英訳を補足しました[http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=_oTRL19x6HwC&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105&dq=kokuhei+chusha%E3%80%80kanpei&source=bl&ots=Bjc1nMwkIz&sig=d3CZGwMjylnmRTwwPnLhV2CAMxQ&hl=ja&ei=VbTLSvHzOYiVkAXdwazfBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=kokuhei%20chusha%E3%80%80kanpei&f=false]。

sen.j: 京都市民からは「てんじんさん」の愛称で呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is affectionately known as 'Tenjin-san' by the people of Kyoto.
It is affectionately known as 'Tenjin-san' by the people of Kyoto.
It is affectionately known as 'Tenjin-san' by the people of Kyoto.

sen.j: 菅原道真を主祭神とし、相殿に中将殿（道真の長子・菅原高視）と吉祥女（道真の正室）を祀る。
sen.e: The main enshrined deity SUGAWARA no Michizane is accompanied by Chujo-dono (SUGAWARA no Takami, the first child of Michizane) and Kisshonyo (the lawful wife of Michizane).
The main enshrined deity SUGAWARA no Michizane is accompanied by Chujo-dono (SUGAWARA no Takami, the first child of Michizane) and Kisshonyo (the lawful wife of Michizane).
The main enshrined deity SUGAWARA no Michizane is accompanied by Chujo-dono (SUGAWARA no Takami, the first child of Michizane) and Kisshonyo (the lawful wife of Michizane).

sen.j: 毎月25日に縁日が開かれ、多くの参拝者や観光客で賑わう。
sen.e: A festival is held on 25th of every month and the temple receives many worshippers and tourists.
A festival is held on the 25th of every month and the temple receives many worshippers and tourists.
A festival is held on the 25th of every month and the temple receives many worshippers and tourists.

sen.j: 特に学問の神として知られ、多くの受験生らの信仰を集めている。
sen.e: As the enshrined deity is known as the patron of scholarship, the shrine is also popular with students preparing for examinations.
As the enshrined deity is known as the patron of scholarship, the shrine is also popular with students preparing for examinations.
As the enshrined deity is known as the patron of scholarship, the shrine is also popular with students preparing for examinations.

sen.j: 京都市が大学の町であることもあってか、掲げられている絵馬には、大学受験合格を祈願するものが多い。
sen.e: Kyoto is a university city and many of the Ema hanging at the shrine have written on them prayers for university exam success.
Kyoto is a university city and many of the Ema hanging at the shrine have written on them prayers for university exam success.
Kyoto City is a city of universities and many of Ema (a votive horse tablet) for getting through a university entrance examination hang in the shrine.
sen.cmt: 「絵馬」の英訳を補足し表現を変えました。

sen.j: 福岡県の太宰府天満宮とともに天神信仰の中心となっており、当社から全国各地に勧請が行われている。
sen.e: Along with Dazaifu-tenmangu Shrine in Fukuoka Prefecture, Kitano-tenmangu Shrine is central to faith in Tenjin, and the enshrined deity has been transferred from the shrine to new locations throughout the country.

Along with Dazaifu-tenmangu Shrine in Fukuoka Prefecture, Kitano-tenmangu Shrine is central to faith in Tenjin, and the enshrined deity has been transferred from the shrine to new locations throughout the country.

Along with Dazaifu-tenmangu Shrine in Fukuoka Prefecture, Kitano-tenmangu Shrine is central to faith in Tenjin, and the divided enshrined deity has been ceremonially transferred from the shrine to new locations throughout the country.

sen.j: 沿革
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 延喜3年（903年）、菅原道真が無実の罪で配流された大宰府で歿した後、都では落雷などの災害が相次いだ。
sen.e: In the 903, the innocent SUGAWARA no Michizane was wrongly exiled to Dazaifu and passed away when, following his death, the capital city was struck by successive disasters including lightning.

In the year 903, the innocent SUGAWARA no Michizane was wrongly exiled to Dazaifu and passed away and then, following his death, the capital city was struck by successive disasters including lightning.
After SUGAWARA no Michizane passed away in 903 in Dazaifu where he was wrongly exiled, a succession of accidents occurred in the capital Kyoto such as lightening strikes.
sen.cmt: 「the year」「the innocent」「 following his death」を除き「disasters」→「accidents」とし（落雷のほか、天皇他関係者の早世が含まれるため）表現を変えました。[http://canpan.info/open/news/0000003698/news_detail.html]

sen.j: これが道真の祟りだとする噂が広まり、御霊信仰と結びついて恐れられた。
sen.e: Rumors spread that the disturbances were a curse brought by Michizane and his vengeful spirit became feared.
Rumors spread that the disturbances were a curse brought by Michizane and his vengeful spirit became feared.
Rumors spread that the disasters were brought by a curse of Michizane, and linked to Goryo-shinko (a folk religious belief of avenging spirits), people feared his vengeful spirit.
sen.cmt: 「御霊信仰と結びついて」を補足し、表現を変えました。

sen.j: そこで、歿後20年目、朝廷は道真の左遷を撤回して官位を復し、正二位を贈った。
sen.e: 20 years after his death, the Imperial Court revoked his demotion, restored his official rank and conferred upon him the senior grade of the second Court rank (Sho-ni-i).
20 years after his death, the Imperial Court revoked his demotion, restored his official rank and conferred upon him the senior grade of the second Court rank (Sho-ni-i).
20 years after his death, the Imperial Court revoked his demotion, restored his official rank and conferred upon him Shonii (Senior Second Rank).
sen.cmt: 「正二位」の表現を他のトピックとあわせました。

sen.j: 天慶5年（942年）、右京七条に住む多治比文子（たじひのあやこ）という少女に託宣があり、それに基づいて天暦元年6月9日 (旧暦)（947年）、現在地の北野の地に朝廷によって道真を祀る社殿が造営された。
sen.e: In 942, a premonition seen by a young lady named TAJIHI no Ayako who lived in Ukyo Shichijo resulted in the main building of the shrine enshrining Michizane being built at its current site in Kitano on 9th day of the 6th month of the year 947.

In 942, a premonition seen by a young lady named TAJIHI no Ayako who lived in Ukyo Shichijo resulted in the main building of the shrine enshrining Michizane being built at its current site in Kitano on the 9th day of the 6th month of the year 947.

According to an oracle in 942 which came to a young lady named TAJIHI no Ayako who lived in Shichijo of Ukyo, the shrine pavilions enshrining Michizane were built in Kitano, the current location, by the Imperial Court in June 29, 947.
sen.cmt: 「朝廷によって」を補足、旧暦を新暦に直し、全体の表現を変えました。

sen.j: 後に藤原師輔（藤原時平の甥であるが、父の藤原忠平が菅原氏と縁戚であったと言われる）が自分の屋敷の建物を寄贈して、壮大な社殿に作り直されたと言う。
sen.e: It is said that FUJIWARA no Morosuke (a nephew of FUJIWARA no Tokihira and the son of FUJIWARA no Tadahira who is said to be related to the Sugawara clan) later donated the buildings from his estate to rebuild the main shrine building in a grand style.

It is said that FUJIWARA no Morosuke (a nephew of FUJIWARA no Tokihira and the son of FUJIWARA no Tadahira who is said to be related to the Sugawara clan) later donated the buildings from his estate to rebuild the main shrine building in a grand style.

It is said that FUJIWARA no Morosuke (a nephew of FUJIWARA no Tokihira and the son of FUJIWARA no Tadahira who is said to be a relative of the Sugawara clan) later donated the buildings of his residence to rebuild the magnificent shrine pavilions.
sen.cmt: 縁戚→a relative、「buildings from his estate」→「buildings of his residence」とし、表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 永延元年（987年）に初めて勅祭が行われ、一条天皇より「北野天満宮天神」の称が贈られた。
sen.e: The first festival held by Imperial order was conducted at the shrine in the year 987 and the name 'Kitano-tenmangu Shrine' was granted to the temple by Emperor Ichijo.
The first festival held by Imperial order was conducted at the shrine in the year 987 and the name 'Kitano-tenmangu Shrine' was granted to the temple by Emperor Ichijo.
The first festival was held by Imperial order in 987 and the name 'Kitano-tenmangu Tenjin' was granted to the shrine by Emperor Ichijo.
sen.cmt: 「 was conducted at the shrine」「the year」を除き「Kitano-tenmangu Shrine」→「Kitano-tenmangu Tenjin」、「temple」→「shrine」としました。

sen.j: 正暦4年（993年）には正一位・右大臣・太政大臣が追贈された。
sen.e: In the year 993, the senior court ranks of Minister of the Right and Chancellor of the Realm were conferred.
In the year 993, the senior court ranks of Minister of the Right and Chancellor of the Realm were conferred.
Shoichii (Senior First Rank), Udaijin (minister of the right) and Dajo-daijin (Grand minister of state) were additionally conferred in 993.
sen.cmt: 「the year」を除き、「additionally」を追加、各位の訳の表現を変えました。"Shonii (Senior First Rank)"→"Shoichii (Senior First Rank)"に変更しました。

sen.j: 以降も朝廷から厚い崇敬を受け、二十二社の一社ともなった。
sen.e: The shrine later became highly revered by the Imperial Court and it was made one of the Twenty-Two Shrines.
The shrine later became highly revered by the Imperial Court and it was made one of the Twenty-Two Shrines.
The shrine later became highly revered by the Imperial Court and it became one of the Twenty-Two Shrines.

sen.j: 中世になっても菅原氏・藤原氏のみならず足利将軍家などからも崇敬を受けた。
sen.e: Even during the medieval period, the shrine was highly revered by all regardless of whether they were of the Sugawara clan, the Fujiwara or the Ashikaga Shogunate family.
Even during the medieval period, the shrine was highly revered by all regardless of whether they were of the Sugawara clan, the Fujiwara clan or the Ashikaga Shogunate family.
Even during the medieval period, the shrine was highly revered by not only the Sugawara clan and the Fujiwara clan but also the Ashikaga Shogunate family.

sen.j: だが、当時北野天満宮を本所としていた麹座の麹製造の独占権を巡るトラブルから文安元年（1444年）に室町幕府の攻撃を受けて天満宮が焼け落ちてしまい、一時衰退する（文安の麹騒動）。
sen.e: However, Kitano-tenmangu Shrine's main office at the time was the Koji-za guild of koji mold (Aspergillus oryzae), producers and a dispute regarding exclusive rights led to an attack by the Muromachi Shorgunate in 1444 in which the shrine was burned to the ground and temporarily plunged into a period of decline (The Koji Crisis of the Bun'an Era).

However, Kitano-tenmangu Shrine's main office at the time was the Koji-za guild of koji mold (Aspergillus oryzae) producers, and a dispute regarding exclusive rights led to an attack by the Muromachi Shogunate in 1444 in which the shrine was burned to the ground and temporarily plunged into a period of decline (The Koji Crisis of the Bun'an Era).

However, Kitano-tenmangu Shrine at the time was the proprietor of the Koji-za (guild of koji (rice malt) manufacturers), and a dispute regarding exclusive rights of manufacturing koji led to an attack in 1444 by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in which the shrine was burned to the ground and temporarily plunged into a period of decline (The Koji Crisis of the Bunan Era).
sen.cmt: 「本所」の訳を修正、「Muromachi Shogunate」→「Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)」とし、前半の表現を変えました。

sen.j: 天正15年（1587年）10月1日、境内において豊臣秀吉による北野大茶湯が催行された。
sen.e: On the 1st day of the 10th month of 1587, the Great Kitano Tea Gathering was held in the grounds of the shrine by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
On the 1st day of the 10th month of 1587, the Great Kitano Tea Gathering was held in the grounds of the shrine by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
On October 1, 1587, the Great Kitano Tea Gathering was held in the precinct by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.
sen.cmt: 年月日の表示および「境内」の訳を他のトピックとあわせました。

sen.j: 境内西側に史跡「御土居」がある。
sen.e: In the western side of the shrine precinct is an earthen rampart - a special historic site.
In the western side of the shrine precinct is an earthen rampart - a special historic site.
A historic site 'Odoi' (an earthen rampart) is in the western side of the shrine precinct.
sen.cmt: 「'」と「御土居」のローマ字読みを補足し、表現を変えました。

sen.j: 江戸時代には道真の御霊としての性格は薄れ、学問の神として広く信仰されるようになり、寺子屋などで当社の分霊が祀られた。
sen.e: During the Edo period, the image of Michizane as a vengeful spirit began to lose favor as he came to be regarded as the patron of scholars, and branch shrines enshrining a division of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine's Tenjin deity were installed at private temple elementary schools.

During the Edo period, the image of Michizane as a vengeful spirit began to lose favor as he came to be regarded as the patron of scholars, and branch shrines enshrining a division of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine's Tenjin deity were installed at private temple elementary schools.

During the Edo period, the image of Michizane as a vengeful spirit began to lose favor as he came to be regarded as the patron of scholars, and divisions of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine's Tenjin deity enshrined in Terakoya (private elementary schools in Edo period).
sen.cmt: 後半の表現を変えました。

sen.j: 1871年（明治4年）に官幣中社に列するとともに「北野神社」と改名させられる。
sen.e: The shrine's title was changed to 'Kitano-jinja Shrine' in 1871 when it was given the rank of Kanpei Chusha.
The shrine's title was changed to 'Kitano-jinja Shrine' in 1871 when it was given the rank of Kanpei Chusha.
In 1871, the shrine was raised to the rank of Kanpei Chusha, and with this, its name was forced to be changed to 'Kitano-jinja.'
sen.cmt: 「title」→「name」「Kitano-jinja Shrine」→「Kitano-jinja」とし表現を変えました。

sen.j: 「宮」を名乗るためには祭神が基本的には皇族であり、かつ勅許が必要であったためである。
sen.e: This was because it was made necessary both for the enshrined deity to be a member of the Imperial household and for imperial permission to be granted in order for a shrine to be allowed to use the suffix '-gu',

This was because it was made necessary both for the enshrined deity to be a member of the Imperial household and for imperial permission to be granted in order for a shrine to be allowed to use the suffix '-gu',

The reasons of renaming was that to address the shrine with the suffix '-gu,' used in the former name, the enshrined deity had to be basically a member of the Imperial household and also the Imperial Court authorized the shrine using the suffix.

sen.j: 旧称の北野天満宮の呼称が復活したのは、戦後の神道国家管理を脱したあとである。
sen.e: The shrine's previous title of 'Kitano-tenmangu Shrine' was restored after the abolition of Governmental Control of State Shinto following the end of the Second World War.
The shrine's previous title of 'Kitano-tenmangu Shrine' was restored after the abolition of Governmental Control of State Shinto following the end of the Second World War.
The shrine's former name of Kitano-tenmangu was restored after the abolition of Governmental Control of State Shinto after the Second World War.
sen.cmt: 「previous title」→「former name」「following the end of」→「after」としました。

sen.j: 1912年には、京都駅との間で、京都市電堀川線（通称北野線）が走るようになった。
sen.e: In 1912, Kyoto City Streetcars started to run to the shrine from Kyoto Station on the Horikawa-line (commonly known as the Kitano-line).
In 1912, Kyoto City Streetcars started to run to the shrine from Kyoto Station on the Horikawa-line (commonly known as the Kitano-line).
In 1912, Kyoto City Streetcars started to run between the shrine and Kyoto Station on the Horikawa-line (commonly known as the Kitano-line).

sen.j: また1958年までは、神社の前まで京福電気鉄道北野線が乗り入れていたが、京都市電今出川線建設のため、北野～白梅町間の路線を市電に譲る形で白梅町（その時北野白梅町駅と改名）止まりとなった。
sen.e: The Keifuku Electric Railway Co. Kitano-Line ran to the front of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine until 1958 when in came to stop at Hakubaicho Station (known as Kitano Hakubaicho station at the time) after the Kitano-Hakubaicho route was turned over to Kyoto City Streetcars due to the construction of the Imadegawa Line.
sen.cmt: 原文の「京福電気鉄道」を１つ削除しましたhttp://www.city.kyoto.jp/koho/eng/historical/first/04.htmlhttp://kaiwai.city.kyoto.jp/raku/modules/information_en/index.php/useful.html
sen.e: The Keifuku Electric Railway Co. Kitano-Line ran to the front of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine until 1958 when in came to stop at Hakubaicho Station (known as Kitano Hakubaicho station at the time) after the Kitano-Hakubaicho route was turned over to Kyoto City Streetcars due to the construction of the Imadegawa Line.

The Keifuku Electric Railway Co. Kitano-Line ran to the front of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine until 1958 when it came to stop at Hakubaicho Station (renamed Kitano Hakubaicho station at the time) on the pretext of turning over the Kitano-Hakubaicho route to Kyoto City Streetcars due to the construction of the Imadegawa Line.
sen.cmt: スペル修正、「known as」→「renamed」、「（譲る）形で」を補足し、表現を少し変えました。

sen.j: 文化財
sen.e: Cultural Properties
Cultural Properties
Cultural Properties

sen.j: 本殿、石の間、拝殿、楽の間（合1棟）
sen.e: Main Shrine, intermediate passageway, worship hall, Raku-no-ma room (one complete structure)
Main Shrine, intermediate passageway, worship hall, Raku-no-ma room (one complete structure)
Main Shrine, Ishi-no-ma (a stone room), worship hall, Raku-no-ma room (all combined into one building)
sen.cmt: 「intermediate passageway」→「Ishi-no-ma (a stone room)」「one complete structure」→「all combined into one building」としました。

sen.j: 紙本着色北野天神縁起 8巻（附 同縁起下絵1巻、梅樹蒔絵箱1合）
sen.e: 8 volume color on paper history of Kitano Tenjin (including 1 sketch, and 1 ume tree makie box)
8 volume color on paper history of Kitano Tenjin (including 1 sketch, and 1 ume tree makie box)
8 volumes of Kitano Tenjin Engi (history of Kitano Tenjin), color painting on paper (including 1 volume of sketch and 1 makie (lacquered craft) box made of ume (plum) tree)
sen.cmt: 「蒔絵」「梅」の英訳を補足し、全体的に修正しました。

sen.j: 中門（三光門）
sen.e: Central gate
Central gate
Central Gate (Three Light Gate)

sen.j: 廻廊 3棟
sen.e: 3 cloisters
3 cloisters
3 cloisters

sen.j: 後門
sen.e: Back gate
Back gate
Back gate

sen.j: 透塀 2棟
sen.e: See-through fence
See-through fence
2 Sukibei (transparent fences)
sen.cmt: 定訳となっていないので、「透塀」のローマ字読みを追加して訳語を変えました。

sen.j: 東門
sen.e: Eastern gate
Eastern gate
Eastern gate

sen.j: 紙本着色北野天神縁起 弘安本 3巻
sen.e: 3 volume color on silk History of Kitano Tenjin, Kouanbon version
3 volume color on silk History of Kitano Tenjin, Kouanbon version
3 volumes of Kitano Tenjin Engi (History of Kitano Tenjin), Koanbon (books painted in Koan era), color painting on paper

sen.j: 紙本着色北野天神縁起 土佐光信筆 3巻
sen.e: 3 volume color on silk History of Kitano Tenjin by Mitsunobu TOSA
3 volume color on silk History of Kitano Tenjin by Mitsunobu TOSA
3 volumes of Kitano Tenjin Engi (History of Kitano Tenjin) by Mitsunobu TOSA, color painting on paper
sen.cmt: 「color on silk」→「color painting on paper」他、補足しました。

sen.j: 紙本着色北野天神縁起 土佐光起筆 3巻
sen.e: 3 volume color on silk History of Kitano Tenjin by Mitsuoki TOSA
3 volume color on silk History of Kitano Tenjin by Mitsuoki TOSA
3 volumes of Kitano Tenjin Engi (History of Kitano Tenjin), painted by Mitsuoki TOSA, color painting on paper
sen.cmt: 「color on silk」→「color painting on paper」他、補足しました。

sen.j: 絹本着色舞楽図 2幀（とう）
sen.e: 2 color on silk bugaku dance paintings
2 color on silk bugaku dance paintings
2 Bugaku-zu (paintings of traditional Japanese court music accompanied by dancing), color painting on silk

sen.j: 紙本墨画雲龍図
sen.e: Ink on paper dragon painting
Ink on paper dragon painting
Unryu-zu (painting of dragon and clouds), monochrome ink painting on paper

sen.j: 板絵金地着色昌俊弁慶相騎図 長谷川等伯筆
sen.e: Gold and silver color on board Votive tablet with illustration of Shoshun Benkei on horseback
Gold and silver color on board Votive tablet with an illustration of Shoshun Benkei on horseback
Votive tablet with an illustration of Shoshun Benkei on horseback, painted by Tohaku HASEGAWA, gold and silver color painting on board

sen.j: 木造鬼神像 13躯
sen.e: 13 wooden statues of demon gods
13 wooden statues of demon gods
13 wooden statues of demon gods

sen.j: 太刀 銘安綱（鬼切）
sen.e: Sword inscribed Yasutsuna (Onikiri)
Sword inscribed Yasutsuna (Onikiri)
Tachi Sword inscribed Yasutsuna (Onikiri)

sen.j: 太刀 銘備州長船師光応永九年（以下不明）
sen.e: Sword inscribed Bishu Osafune Moromitsu, Oei 9 (rest unclear)
Sword inscribed Bishu Osafune Moromitsu, Oei 9 (rest unclear)
Tachi Sword inscribed Bishu Osafune Moromitsu, the year 9 in the Oei era (rest unclear)

sen.j: 太刀 銘助守
sen.e: Sword inscribed Sukemori
Sword inscribed Sukemori
Tachi Sword inscribed Sukemori

sen.j: 太刀 銘恒次
sen.e: Sword inscribed Tsunetsugu
Sword inscribed Tsunetsugu
Tachi Sword inscribed Tsunetsugu

sen.j: 刀 銘北野天満天神豊臣秀頼公御造営之寺于時慶長十二丁未十一月日信濃守国広造

sen.j: 交通
sen.e: Access
Access
Access

sen.j: 京都市バス「北野天満宮前」バス停から下車すぐ。
sen.e: Soon reached by foot from Kyoto City Bus 'Mitano Tenmangu mae' bus stop.
Soon reached by foot from Kyoto City Bus 'Mitano Tenmangu mae' bus stop.
Soon reached on foot from 'Mitano Tenmangu mae' bus stop of Kyoto City Bus.
sen.cmt: 「Mitano Tenmangu mae」→「Kitano Tenmangu mae」とし、順序を変えました。

sen.j: なお、当社の北門は桜の名所でもある平野神社にほど近く、北門から平野神社の中を通って西大路通りの衣笠校前バス停に行くこともできる。
sen.e: The shrine's northern gate stands near to the Hirano-jija Shrine, famous for its sakura cherry blossom, and the Kinugasako mae bus stop on Nishi Oji-dori Street can be reached by passing through Hirano-jinja Shrine from the northern gate.

The shrine's northern gate stands near to the Hirano-jija Shrine, famous for its sakura cherry blossom, and the Kinugasako mae bus stop on Nishi Oji-dori Street can be reached by passing through Hirano-jinja Shrine from the northern gate.

The shrine's northern gate stands near Hirano-jinja Shrine, famous for its sakura cherry blossom, and the Kinugasako mae bus stop on Nishi Oji-dori Street can be reached by passing through Hirano-jinja Shrine from the northern gate.

sen.j: 北野天満宮や菅原道真は、ウメおよびウシとの関係が深い。
sen.e: Kitano-tenmangu Shrine and SUGAWARA no Michizane have a deep relationship with ume and the bull.
Kitano-tenmangu Shrine and SUGAWARA no Michizane have a deep relationship with ume and the bull.
Kitano-tenmangu Shrine and SUGAWARA no Michizane have a deep relationship with ume and bulls.

sen.j: 道真は梅をこよなく愛し、大宰府左遷の際、庭の梅に「東風（こち）吹かば 匂い起こせよ 梅の花 主なしとて 春な忘れそ（現在は「春を忘るな」とされることもある）」と和歌を詠みました。
sen.e: Michizane was very fond of ume and composed the waka poem 'Kochi fukaba Nioi okoseyo ume no hana aruji nasitote haruna wasureso (now, haruwo wasuruna)' lamenting the loss of his beloved ume tree that as left behind in the capital following his demotion and exile to Dazaifu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Michizane was very fond of ume and composed the waka poem 'Kochi fukaba Nioi okoseyo ume no hana aruji nasitote haruna wasureso (now, haruwo wasuruna)' lamenting the loss of his beloved ume tree that was left behind in the capital following his demotion and exile to Dazaifu.

Michizane was very fond of ume and composed the waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) to the ume tree in his garden, 'Kochi fukaba Nioi okoseyo ume no hana aruji nasitote haruna wasureso (recently haruwo wasuruna)' (Whenever the east wind blows, my dear plum blossoms remember spring, even if your master won't be here), following his demotion and exile to Dazaifu.
sen.cmt: 「和歌」の英訳を補足しました。[http://canpan.info/open/news/0000003698/news_detail.html]

sen.j: その梅が菅原道真を慕って一晩のうちに大宰府に飛来したという飛梅伝説ができたことから、梅が神紋となっている。
sen.e: The ume tree of the shrine's crest comes from the Legend of Tobiume (flying ume tree), which tells that the ume tree so longed to be with SUGAWARA no Michizane that one night it flew to Dazaifu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The ume tree of the shrine's crest comes from the Legend of Tobiume (flying ume tree), which tells that the ume tree so longed to be with SUGAWARA no Michizane that one night it flew to Dazaifu.
The ume tree of the shrine's crest comes from the Legend of Tobiume (flying ume tree), which tells that the ume tree so longed to be with SUGAWARA no Michizane that one night it flew to Dazaifu.

sen.j: そのことにちなみ境内には梅が多く植えられている。
sen.e: It is for this reason that numerous ume trees grow within the shrine precinct.
It is for this reason that numerous ume trees grow within the shrine precinct.
It is for this reason that numerous ume trees grow within the shrine precinct.

sen.j: （楼門外には梅林もあり、シーズン中は有料で公開される。
sen.e: (an ume tree forest grows outside of the romon gate and is open to the public for a fee when in season).
(an ume tree forest grows outside of the romon gate and is open to the public for a fee when in season).
(an ume tree forest grows outside of the romon gate (two-storey gate) and is open to the public for a fee when in season).
sen.cmt: 「楼門」の英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: ） 梅の花の咲く頃は受験シーズンであるので受験生やその家族の参拝がもともと多いが、加えて観梅の観光客も多く訪れる。
sen.e: These trees blossom at the same time of year as the school examination season so it is during this period that the shrine receives the greatest number of students and their families in addition to increased numbers of tourists who visit to see the ume blossom.

These trees blossom at the same time of year as the school examination season so it is during this period that the shrine receives the greatest number of students and their families in addition to increased numbers of tourists who visit to see the ume blossom.

These trees blossom at the same time of year as the school examination season so it is during this period that the shrine receives the greatest number of students and their families in addition to increased numbers of tourists who visit to see the ume blossom.

sen.j: 牛は天満宮において神使（祭神の使者）とされているが、その理由については「道真の出生年は丑年である」「亡くなったのが丑の月の丑の日である」「道真は牛に乗り大宰府へ下った」「牛が刺客から道真を守った」「道真の墓所（太宰府天満宮）の位置は牛が決めた」など多くの伝承があります。
sen.e: Tenman-gu Shrine also enshrines the bull as a familiar spirit (a familiar spirit for the enshrined deity) as there are many legends that link Michizane to the bull, including those that claim that 'Michizane was born in the year of the bull', 'died in the day of the bull in the month of the bull', 'Michizane rode a bull to Dazaifu', 'a bull saved Michizane from an assassin', and 'a bull decided the location of Minchizane's grave (Dazaifu Tenman-gu Shrine)'.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tenman-gu Shrine also enshrines the bull as a familiar spirit (a familiar spirit for the enshrined deity) as there are many legends that link Michizane to the bull, including those that claim that 'Michizane was born in the year of the bull', 'died on the day of the bull in the month of the bull', 'Michizane rode a bull to Dazaifu', 'a bull saved Michizane from an assassin', and 'a bull decided the location of Minchizane's grave (Dazaifu Tenman-gu Shrine)'.

Tenman-gu Shrine also enshrines the bull as a shinshi (a messenger of the enshrined deity) as there are many legends that link Michizane to the bull, including those that claim that 'Michizane was born in the year of the bull (in chinese calendar),' 'died on the day of the bull in the month of the bull (in chinese calendar),' 'Michizane rode a bull to Dazaifu,' 'a bull saved Michizane from an assassin,' and 'a bull decided the location of Minchizane's grave (Dazaifu Tenman-gu Shrine).'
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を買え、「in chinese calendar」を補足しました。

sen.j: どれが真実なのか、それとも全て伝承に過ぎないのかは今となっては良くわからないものの、それらの伝承にちなみ北野天満宮には神使とされる臥牛の像が多数置かれている。
sen.e: It is not known which are true and which are merely legend but the grounds of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine contain many statues of bulls in a lying down position that are believed to serve as familiar spirits.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is not known which are true and which are merely legend but the grounds of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine contain many statues of bulls in a lying down position that are believed to serve as familiar spirits.
It is not known which are true and which are merely legend but the grounds of Kitano-tenmangu Shrine contain many statues of bulls in a lying down position that are believed to serve as shinshi.

sen.j: 伝承のうち「牛が刺客から道真を守った」というのは和気清麻呂を祭神とする護王神社のイノシシの伝承との関連性が強く認められる。
sen.e: Of these legends, the one that 'a bull saved Michizane from an assassin' is strongly related to the wild boar legend of Goo-jinja Shrine enshrining WAKE no Kiyomaro.
Of these legends, the one that 'a bull saved Michizane from an assassin' is strongly related to the wild boar legend of Goo-jinja Shrine enshrining WAKE no Kiyomaro.
Of these legends, the one that 'a bull saved Michizane from an assassin' is recognized strong relation with the wild boar legend of Go-jinja Shrine enshrining WAKE no Kiyomaro.
sen.cmt: 「認められる」を補足しました。
